children.name: to tell sb that you are sorry you did sth
say you are sorry
children.definition: to tell sb you are sorry that you haveupsetthem ordonesth that causes problems for them:nói lời xin lỗi
examples: Sometimes it’s not easy to say you are sorry.
say you are sorry (that)
She finally arrived, and said she was sorry we had been kept waiting.

children.name: say sorry
children.definition: especiallyspokento tell someone that you are sorry you haveupsetthem ordonesomething bad:xin lỗi
examples: ▪ She says she won’t see him again unless he says sorry.
say sorry to
▪ Go and say sorry to your mother, Andrew.
say sorry for (doing) sth
▪ I don’t think I should say sorry for doing what at the time I believed to be right.

children.name: apologize
children.definition: /apologiseUK  to tell sb that you are sorry, especially in aformalsituation or when youdo not know the person well:xin lỗi
examples: I don’t know why I apologized, because I didn’t do anything wrong.
apologize for
I must apologize for my son’s behaviour -- he isn’t usually this moody.
apologize for doing sth
The bank wrote to apologise for overcharging me.
apologize to
The US has apologized to Britain for the accident that cost nine British lives.
apologize profuselyapologize very muchxin lỗi rối rít
She rushed into the hotel, apologizing profusely for being so late.

children.name: apologetic
children.definition: showing or saying that you are sorry that sth has happened, especially because you feel guilty or embarrassed about it : hối tiếc, hối hận, hối lỗi
examples: She gave me anapologetic smile.
I hope he was suitably apologeticforbreaking your glasses.
The manager was apologetic, but said that Sue would have to contact head office if she wanted a refund.
apologetic about
He was most apologetic about not being able to come to the party.
The manager was very apologetic about everything.
look/sound apologetic
Dan came in looking very apologetic.
apologetically[adv]
‘I know,’ she said apologetically.

children.name: apology
children.definition: sth that you say or write to show that you are sorry for doing sth wrong
examples: apology for
The minister had to issue a formal public apology for his remarks.
apology from
She finally received an apology from the company.
apology to
an apology to passengers for any inconvenience caused
make an apologyI hope you are going to make an apology.
issue an apology(= make an official public apology )North Korea issued an official apology for the incident.
get/receive an apologyHe received a formal apology from the company.
offer an apologyWe would like to offer our sincere apologies for the delay.
accept sb’s apologyPlease accept my apologies for having to cancel our meeting.
demand an apologyChina continued to demand a full apology from the US.
owe sb an apologyI’m afraid I owe you an apology.
publish an apology(= print it in a newspaper )The newspaper group was forced to publish a full apology.
mumble/mutter an apology(= say it quietly, especially because you are embarrassed )He bumped into me and mumbled an apology.

my sincere/profound apologies(= used when you feel very sorry )Firstly, my sincere apologies for not having contacted you earlier.|‘I have been guilty of making some insensitive remarks,’ said Wright, who offered his profound apologies to everyone concerned.
a public apologyThe authorities published a public apology in the newspaper.
a formal apologyRussia is demanding a formal apology.
an official apologyThe company has made an official apology and is offering compensation.
a written apologyThe police sent a written apology to the family.
a full apologyThe Prime Minister made a full apology in the House of Commons.
an abject apologyformal(= one that shows that you are very sorry )The BBC issued an abject apology for insulting the Queen.
profuse apologiesformal(= when someone says that they are sorry several times )Moira telephoned with profuse apologies for the misunderstanding.
a letter of apologyWe agreed to write a letter of apology.

children.name: I'm afraid
children.definition: ...tôi e là
examples: used to politely introduce bad news or disagreement
_This is your room - it's rather small, I'm afraid.
_I don't agree at all, I'm afraid.
_I'm afraid you've completely misunderstood the question.
_[ + ( that ) ]I'm afraid(that)we can't come this evening after all.
_"Was she impressed with our work?" "I'm afraid not (= No) ."
_"Does this mean I've got to leave?" "I'm afraid so (= Yes) ."

children.name: forgiveness
children.definition: noun sự tha thứ
examples: the act of forgiving or the willingness to forgive
_to ask for/beg forgiveness
_ he asked forgiveness for what he had done wrong
hắn xin được tha thứ về những lỗi lầm của mình
_ the forgiveness of sins sự xá tội; sự ân xá
_ she is sympathetic and full of forgiveess cô ây luôn cảm thông và đầy lòng khoan dung

children.name: make no apology for sth
children.definition: make no apology for somethingto not say that you are sorry for something, because you do not regret it and you think it is the right thing to do :
examples: We make no apology for defending our members’ interests – that is our job.

children.name: make up
children.definition: alsomake it upBritish /ˌmeɪk ˈʌp, ˌmeɪk ɪt ˈʌp/  especially spoken if two people who know each other well make up or make it up, they stop arguing and start being friendly to each other again:
examples: làm hòa
▪ I’m glad to see you two have made up.Tôi vui mừng khi thấy hai người làm hòa
make up with làm hòa với
▪ Have you made it up with your sister yet?Bạn đã làm hòa vơi em gái bạn chưa ?

children.name: settle your differences
children.definition: patch up your differences//ˌpætʃ ʌp jɔːʳˈdɪfərənsz, ˌsetl jɔːʳ ˈdɪfərənsz/  iftwopeopleororganizationspatch up or settle their differences, they stop arguing and discuss things in a sensible way until they come to an agreement: giải quyết mâu thuẫn
examples: ▪ Their final attempt to settle their differences ended in disappointment and separation.
patch up your differences/settle your differences with
▪ Gary’s first priority on his return home was to patch up his differences with his sister.

children.name: bury the hatchet
children.definition: /ˌberi ðə ˈhætʃt/  to agree to stop arguing and forgive each other, especiallya long timeafter you first had the argument:
examples: làm lành
▪ It’s about time they buried the hatchet after all these years.
Đó là thời gian họ làm lành sau nhiều năm
▪ Since those two buried the hatchet, life in the office has been much quieter.
Kể từ khi hai người làm lành, cuộc sống trong văn phòng yêu tĩnh hơn

children.name: clear the air
children.definition: /ˌklɪəʳ ði ˈeəʳ/  to talk calmly and seriously with someone about what you have been arguing about, in order to end the disagreement and feel better:
examples: xua tan không khí nặng nề
▪ I think it’s about time you called her to clear the air.
Tôi nghĩ đây là thời gian bạn gọi cô ấy để xua tan không khí nặng nề.
▪ In an attempt to clear the air, Mills has planned a meeting with employees to discuss the issue.
Trong nổi lực xua tan không khí nặng nề, Nills đã lên kế hoạch một cuộc gặp gỡ với nhân viên để thảo luận về vấn đề này.

children.name: conciliatory
children.definition: /kənˈsɪliətəriǁ-tɔːri/  behaving in a way that shows that you want to end an argument with someone: hòa giải
examples: ▪ The tone of my letter had been friendly and conciliatory, so I was disappointed by the cold reply I received.
Giọng điều trong thư của tôi đã thân thiện và hòa giải, vì vậy tôi đã cảm thấy thất vọng bơi sự trả lời lạnh lẽo tôi nhận được
conciliatory gesture/message/tone etc : cử chỉ / tin nhắn / giọng điệu hòagiải
▪ American intelligence flights over Cuba had been stopped as a conciliatory gesture.
Các chuyến bay tình báo của Hòa Kỳ trên Cuba đã bị dừng lại như một cử chỉ hòa giải

children.name: reconciliation
children.definition: /ˌrekənsɪliˈeɪʃən/  when two people, countries etc agree to stop arguing or fighting after a long period of disagreement, and have a friendly relationship again:
examples: sự giảng hòa, hòa giải
▪ After years of fighting, there was now a spirit of national reconciliation in South Africa.
Sau nhiều năm chiến tranh, giờ đây đã có một tinh thần hòa giải dân tộc ở Nam Phi
reconciliation with : sự hòa giải với
▪ Giles is not interested in a reconciliation with his father.
Giles không quan tâm đến việc hòa giả với cha của anh ấy.
reconciliation between : sự hòa giải giữa
▪ A large group of demonstrators stayed up all night praying for reconciliation between the two countries.
Một nhóm lớn người biểu tình ở lại suốt đêm cầu nguyện để hòa giải giữa hai nước.

children.name: excuse me
children.definition: excuse
examples: excuse mespokena polite way of attracting someone's attention, especially of sb you do not know,especially when you want to ask a question:
Excuse me, can you tell me the way to the museum please?
Excuse me, does this bus go to Oxford Street?

children.name: pardon me
children.definition: spokenused to politely get sb’s attention in order to ask them a questionSYN excuse me:
examples: Pardon me, can you direct me to City Hall?
pardon me for interrupting/asking/sayingspokenused to politely ask if you can interrupt someone, ask them a question, or tell them something :
Pardon me for saying so, but you don’t look well.

children.name: forgive me
children.definition: spokenformal say this when you have done sth wrong or have upset sb: thứ lỗi cho tôi
examples: Forgive me, butI don’t think that is relevant.
forgive me for doing sth
Forgive me for asking, but how much did you pay for your bag?
Forgive me for asking, but how old are you?
Forgive me for saying this, but you really don’t look well at all.
forgive me for asking/saying etc sth
Forgive me for saying so, but that’s nonsense.

children.name: excuse me
children.definition: excuse
examples: excuse mespokenused to politely ask sb to move so that you can walk past them:
Excuse me, could I just squeeze past?
Excuse me, can I just get past?

children.name: make your apologies
children.definition: to say that you are sorry but you have to leave : xin phép
examples: I quickly made my apologies and left.

children.name: excuse me
children.definition: excuse
examples: excuse mespokenused to politely tell sb that you are leaving a place : xin phép
Excuse me a moment. I’ll be right back.
Excuse me a moment, I'll be with you shortly.

children.name: for having done sth by accident
pardon me
children.definition: spokenused to say ‘sorry’ politely when you have accidentally pushed sb or interrupted them :
examples: Oh, pardon me, I didn’t mean to disturb you.
pardon me[VP] spokenused to say ‘sorry’ politely after you have made an impolite sound such as a burp

children.name: I beg your pardon
children.definition: formal spokenused to say sorry when you have made a mistake, or said sth wrong or embarrassing :
examples: ‘That’s my pen.’ ‘Oh, I beg your pardon - I thought it was mine.’
Oh, I beg your pardon. I thought you said 15 pence, not 50.

children.name: excuse me
children.definition: excuse
examples: excuse mespokenespecially USused to say sorry for sth rude or embarrassing you have done by accident:
Oh, excuse me. I didn’t know anyone was here.
Did I take your seat? Do excuse me.
Oh, excuse me, is that your bag I just stood on?
Excuse me - I didn’t realize there was anyone in here.

children.name: when you can't be present sw
apologies
children.definition: formala message that you send to a meeting to say that you will not be able to come to the meeting : lời xin lỗivắng mặt
examples: Apologies were received from Phil Baker and Malcolm Johnson.
send your apologies
Edward can’t be here today, but hesendshisapologies.
The vice-chair hassenthis apologies - he's abroad at present.

children.name: excuse me
children.definition: excuse
examples: excuse mespokenused when you disagree with sb but want to be polite about itSYN I’m sorry:
Excuse me, but I don’t think that’s what he meant at all.
Excuse me but aren't you forgetting something?
excuse[T]
excuse mespokenUSused to show that you disagree with sb or are very surprised or upset by what they have just said :
‘You’re going to pay, right?’ ‘Excuse me?’

children.name: pardon me
children.definition: spokenused before you politely correct sb or disagree with them :
examples: James, if you’ll pardon me, you’ve got it all wrong.

children.name: pardon
children.definition: / pardon meUS/I beg your pardonformal or humorous  used to show that sb has said sth that offends you:
examples: "Women tend to be fairly useless drivers, anyway." "I beg your pardon!"
I beg your pardon? I hope you're not implying that I lied!

children.name: sorry
children.definition: / I’m sorryB2 spokenused when you disagree with sb, or tell sb that they have done sth wrong :
examples: I’m sorry, but I find that very hard to believe, Miss Brannigan.

children.name: for sth you have done or said
sorry
children.definition: /I’m sorry/ˈsɒri, aɪm ˈsɒriǁ-ˈsɑːri/ spoken say this to tell someone you are sorry that you upset them or caused problems for them; you can also say this as a polite way of excusing yourself for a small mistake: xin lỗi/tôi xin lỗi
examples: ▪ I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to be rude.
▪ Sorry, did I step on your foot?
I’m very/really/terribly sorry
▪ I’m really sorry, Joanna. I’ve broken one of your glasses.
sorry/I’m sorry (that)
▪ I’m sorry that I shouted at you.
▪ Sorry we’re late, Shelley.
sorry/I’m sorry about
▪ Sorry about all the noise.
sorry/I’m sorry to do something
▪ I’m sorry to bother you, but I need to discuss my essay.
sorry/I’m sorry for (doing something)
▪ I’m sorry for barging in without ringing the bell.
sorryadjectiveAPOLOGY sorry for / about something
[ after verb ]used to say that you wish you had not done what you have done,
especially when you want to be polite to someone you have done something bad to
_Oh, I'm sorry - I didn't see you there.
_Tom, I'm so sorryaboutlast night - it was all my fault.
_I'vesaidI'm sorry.

children.name: excuse
children.definition: to forgive sb for doing sth that is not seriously wrong, such as being rude or careless : thứ lỗi
examples: I’ll excuse you this time, but don’t be late again.
excuse sth
Nothing can excuse that sort of behaviour.
Please excuse my bad handwriting.
excuse sb for (doing) sth
We cannot excuse him for these crimes.
Please excuse me for being so late today.
Smithcan be excusedfor his lack of interest in the course(= his lack of interest is reasonable ).
excuse sb from
I asked the teacher if I could be excused from(= allowed not to do)football practice as my knee still hurt.
Please excuse me from(= allow me to miss)the rest of the meeting - I've just received a phone call that requires my immediate attention.
RegisterIn informal situations, people often saysorry about …, sorry for doing ...orsorry I …rather than asking sb toexcusesth:
Sorry aboutmy handwriting.
Sorry for beingso late. ORSorry I’mso late.

children.name: pardon
children.definition: formalto forgive someone for something they have said or done. this word is often used in polite expressions:SYN forgive
examples: pardon sth
Pardon my ignorance, but what exactly is ergonomics?
pardon sb for sth
He could never pardon her for the things she had said.
pardon sb doing sth
Pardon me interrupting , but there's a client to see you.
pardon my ignorance/rudeness etcspokenused when you want to say something which you think may make you seem not to know enough or not to be polite enough :
Pardon my ignorance, but what does OPEC stand for?

children.name: I owe you an apology
children.definition: say this when you have done sth that you later find out to be wrong or unfair: tôi nợ một lời xin lỗi
examples: It seems I owe you an apology -- I was supposed to phone you on Saturday night.
I owe you an apology for
I think I owe you an apology for my behaviour the other night.

children.name: I apologize
children.definition: / I apologiseUS  spoken say this to apologize in a fairly formal way, for example when you have upset sb or done sth wrong or unfair: tôi xin lỗi
examples: You were right and I was wrong.
I apologize in advance
I apologize in advance if anyone’s offended by this.
I apologize for
I apologise for writing to you like this, out of the blue.

children.name: please accept my apologies
children.definition: used in formal letters: hãy chấp nhận lời xin lỗi của tôi
examples: ▪ Please accept my apologies. I will be taking steps to ensure this does not happen again.
please accept my apologies for
▪ Please accept my apologies for any inconvenience this error has caused.

children.name: forgive me
children.definition: spokenformal say this when you are going to say or ask sth that might seem rude or offensive: thứ lỗi cho tôi
examples: Forgive me, I didn’t mean to offend you.
forgive me for doing sth

children.name: sorry
children.definition: /I’m sorryB2 spokenused to tell sb that you wish you had not done sth that has affected them badly, hurt them etc :
examples: I’m really sorry. I didn’t mean to hurt your feelings.
‘Matt, stop doing that!’ ‘Sorry!’
I’m sorry, did I step on your foot?
sorry (that)
I’m sorry I’m late – the traffic was terrible.
sorry/I’m sorry about
Sorry about the mess – I’ll clean it up.
sorry for (doing) sth
I’m sorry for making such a fuss.
Sorry to bother you, but what was the address again?

children.name: for refusing an offer or request
sorry
children.definition: /I’m sorryB2 spokenused when you refuse an offer or request :
examples: ‘Are you coming to lunch?’ ‘Sorry, no. I’ve got to finish this work.’
‘I’ll give you $50 for it.’ ‘Sorry, no deal.’

children.name: sorry
children.definition: /I’m sorryB2 spokenused as a polite way of introducing disappointing information or a piece of bad news :
examples: I’m sorry, but all the flights to Athens are fully booked.

children.name: sorry
children.definition: spokenused when you have said sth that is not correct, and want to say something that is correct :
examples: Turn right – sorry left – at the traffic lights.
